fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A sequent over a signature \Sigma is a formal expression of the form \Gamma | \varphi \vdash \psi, where \varphi and \psi are formulas and \Gamma is a context suitable for both \varphi and \psi.
A context is a finite list of distinct variables. A context is said to be suitable for a formula (resp., term) if every free variable of that formula (resp., term) appears in the given context.
A (first-order) signature \Sigma consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: A collection of function symbols, each comes with a prescribed type denoted as follows: f \colon A_{1}, \ldots ,A_{n} \to B where A_{1}, \ldots ,A_{n},B are sorts. Unary (n = 0) function symbols are also called constant symbols.

A collection of relation symbols, each comes with a prescribed type denoted as follows: R \rightarrowtail A_{1}, \ldots ,A_{n} where A_{1}, \ldots ,A_{n} are sorts. Unary (n = 0) relation symbols are usually called atomic propositions.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Each sort comes with a collection of variables. We assume that given any collection of variables of sort A, there is a variable of sort A not in the given collection.
An axiomatization of a theory \mathscr { T } over a signature \Sigma is a collection of sequents over \Sigma. These sequents are the (non-logical) axioms of (the axiomatization of) \mathscr { T }.
Let M be a \Sigma-structure in a category \mathcal { C }.

fr:ul.fr:li: Let \sigma = \Gamma | \varphi \vdash \psi be a sequent interpretable in \mathcal { C }. \sigma is satisfied in M, denoted as M \vDash \sigma, if { \mathopen {} \llbracket \Gamma . \varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}} _{ M } \leq { \mathopen {} \llbracket \Gamma . \psi \rrbracket \mathclose {}} _{ M } in the preorder \mathsf { Sub } (M( \Gamma )).
Fix an axiomatization of a theory \mathscr { T }. M is a model of \mathscr { T }, denoted as M \vDash \mathscr { T }, if every axiom of (the given axiomatization of) \mathscr { T } is satisfied.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The category \mathscr { T } \text {-} \mathsf {Mod} ( \mathcal { C } ) is the full subcategory of \Sigma \text {-} \mathsf {Str} ( \mathcal { C } ) spanned by models of \mathscr { T }, and the category \mathscr { T } \text {-} \mathsf {Mod} ( \mathcal { C } )_{e} has the same objects as \mathscr { T } \text {-} \mathsf {Mod} ( \mathcal { C } ) except morphisms are elementary morphisms.
